Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A Smartphone-Human Hybrid System to Measure Human Behavior and Well-Being
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project centers on accurate and comprehensive collection of human behavioral and well-being data for improved policymaking and business operations. The proposed system provides a new way to collect human behavior and well-being data. It has the potential to help government agencies design more livable neighborhoods, cities, and regions for greater human well-being. The technology may also help companies demonstrate that their products and services improve behavioral and well-being outcomes. In addition, the increasing prevalence of smartphone ownership makes the proposed system widely accessible for large-scale deployment. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project features a smartphone-human hybrid intelligence system that incorporates advanced data mining and machine learning techniques and sophisticated user interface design to allow interactions between smartphone- and human-generated data. Specifically, smartphone sensor data are analyzed locally on the phone and in real time using data mining and machine learning algorithms to extract objective, spatiotemporal details of daily activities and trips. The extracted information reduces respondent burden and serves as an initial information basis to attach more detailed and accurate information on daily activities and trips. The information from the human user, in turn, optimizes the data mining and machine learning algorithms for analyzing smartphone sensor data and increases accuracy in smartphone-generated data over time. The result is a novel system in which smartphone sensing collaborates with human input to generate accurate and comprehensive data related to human behavior and well-being.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the team developed marketing strategies for the Daynamica app, which integrates mobile GPS sensing with subjective data entered by users to collect human activity and well-being data throughout the day. To identify market segments, we conducted 103 online customer discovery interviews. The interviews focused on two major sectors. One is clinicians and healthcare providers, and another is academic researchers who study human behavior. After the interviews with these two customer segments, we narrowed down our validated customer segments to academic researchers who studies people?s ?everyday life? activities and experiences.

More specifically, ?everyday life? speaks to the ordinary activities and experiences that most people encounter daily. Although mundane and unremarkable by definition, everyday life activities and experiences are shared by most people, play essential roles in shaping human health and well-being, and constitute much of the basis of societal development and progress. With greater accuracy, more comprehensiveness, and minimal respondent burden in generating human activity and well-being data, the Daynamica technology provides unprecedented opportunities for social and health researchers to understand everyday life and make new discoveries. The technology has spurred a wealth of new research, including at least six doctoral dissertations, 20 research grants, and 30 peer-reviewed publications.

As a result of this grant, we hosted a one-day, in-person symposium titled "Understanding Everyday Life: Advancing Social and Health Sciences through Digital Day Reconstruction" at the University of Minnesota campus on July 29, 2022. The symposium highlighted how researchers at the University of Minnesota and beyond have used the Daynamica app to advance research in social & health sciences. Speakers in the symposium explored a wide range of topics, ranging from time use and health outcomes among at-risk populations and during COVID to the effects of environmental exposure on health disparities. More than 70 people participated in the symposium, including academics from a wide range of disciplines as well as practitioners from the public and private sectors. The event also provided participants networking opportunities to explore possible synergies and future partnerships for understanding the 5Ws (Who, What, When, Why, and Where) of daily living activities and experiences.

The project also helped the team to identify commercialization opportunities in the field of digital health. On June 15, 2022, the team was awarded Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) grant from the National Institutes of Health to continue developing the Daynamica technology into a digital health tool for remote patient monitoring.  

 

 


Last Modified: 11/09/2022
Modified by: Yingling Fan

One is clinicians and healthcare providers, and another is academic researchers who study human behavior. After the interviews with these two customer segments, we narrowed down our validated customer segments to academic researchers who studies people?s ?everyday life? activities and experiences. More specifically, ?everyday life? speaks to the ordinary activities and experiences that most people encounter daily. Although mundane and unremarkable by definition, everyday life activities and experiences are shared by most people, play essential roles in shaping human health and well-being, and constitute much of the basis of societal development and progress. With greater accuracy, more comprehensiveness, and minimal respondent burden in generating human activity and well-being data, the Daynamica technology provides unprecedented opportunities for social and health researchers to understand everyday life and make new discoveries. The technology has spurred a wealth of new research, including at least six doctoral dissertations, 20 research grants, and 30 peer-reviewed publications. The event also provided participants networking opportunities to explore possible synergies and future partnerships for understanding the 5Ws (Who, What, When, Why, and Where) of daily living activities and experiences.
